body_html:
Here are a few general guidelines:

  • Everything in contrib is experimental. Some of it may move to core (tf.estimator is a piece of contrib.learn which moved to core), some of it may not.
  • There are strong API guarantees for things not in contrib, there are no such guarantees in contrib.
  • Nevertheless, we avoid removing things without notice, so this process leaves duplicates (often with slight differences) in contrib.
  • We will mark a lot of things in contrib to be explicitly deprecated in the coming months to make this clearer.
  • Consequently, if there is an option to use that's not in contrib, use it. It's safe, won't change, and won't be removed.
  • tf.layers in fact does work (mostly) with tf.keras. tf.keras is a full implementation of the Keras 2.0 spec, which is partly collected from other places in TensorFlow via simple aliases, and partly by extending functionality implemented elsewhere. If you rely on compatibility with Keras, use tf.keras. Mixing with other things in TensorFlow is generally ok, but some things may not work (e.g. tf.layers.Dense does not currently support serialization). All of TensorFlow can be used with tf.estimator.

I know the current state of contrib is confusing, and we're working on cleaning it up.
body_text:
Here are a few general guidelines:

Everything in contrib is experimental. Some of it may move to core (tf.estimator is a piece of contrib.learn which moved to core), some of it may not.
There are strong API guarantees for things not in contrib, there are no such guarantees in contrib.
Nevertheless, we avoid removing things without notice, so this process leaves duplicates (often with slight differences) in contrib.
We will mark a lot of things in contrib to be explicitly deprecated in the coming months to make this clearer.
Consequently, if there is an option to use that's not in contrib, use it. It's safe, won't change, and won't be removed.
tf.layers in fact does work (mostly) with tf.keras. tf.keras is a full implementation of the Keras 2.0 spec, which is partly collected from other places in TensorFlow via simple aliases, and partly by extending functionality implemented elsewhere. If you rely on compatibility with Keras, use tf.keras. Mixing with other things in TensorFlow is generally ok, but some things may not work (e.g. tf.layers.Dense does not currently support serialization). All of TensorFlow can be used with tf.estimator.

I know the current state of contrib is confusing, and we're working on cleaning it up.
body:
Here are a few general guidelines:

- Everything in contrib is experimental. Some of it may move to core (tf.estimator is a piece of contrib.learn which moved to core), some of it may not. 
- There are strong API guarantees for things not in contrib, there are no such guarantees in contrib.
- Nevertheless, we avoid removing things without notice, so this process leaves duplicates (often with slight differences) in contrib.
- We will mark a lot of things in contrib to be explicitly deprecated in the coming months to make this clearer.
- Consequently, if there is an option to use that's not in contrib, use it. It's safe, won't change, and won't be removed.
- tf.layers in fact does work (mostly) with tf.keras. tf.keras is a full implementation of the Keras 2.0 spec, which is partly collected from other places in TensorFlow via simple aliases, and partly by extending functionality implemented elsewhere. If you rely on compatibility with Keras, use tf.keras. Mixing with other things in TensorFlow is generally ok, but some things may not work (e.g. tf.layers.Dense does not currently support serialization). All of TensorFlow can be used with tf.estimator.

I know the current state of contrib is confusing, and we're working on cleaning it up.
